Description: Roughly rectangular, oblong object, finished at three sides, the fourth broken off. Outer surface smooth with four incised circles with central dot; small drilled hole near one of the finished edges, possibly so as to attach the piece to another object (as inlay?). Carved from large mammal bone then polished and incised.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The design of dotted circles can be found on many types of objects, such as handles (handle found in Cyprus: BM 1974,1101.14), plaques (plaques from the Temple of Artemis Orthia BM 1923,0212.611 -614) or even amuletic pendants (amulets from the Levant, normally dated to the 9th-8th century BC: Herrmann et al, 174; many pendants from Casviri cemetery in Kamiros, dated to the Orientalising Period, such as BM 1864,1007.618-620 and BM 1864,1007.664). A Greek, Cypriot or Levant origin is possible for such artefact, though an Egyptian one cannot be ruled out either. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WB.13) (Phase 3)
